In a general sense, though, there was a threat of physical violence if a certain individual didn't leave campus because of his personal life-style choice. Also, there are very few African-Americans at the school, as well as Asians, or other groups. It seems there are only as many as will fit the quota, but, on a side note, Hampden-Sydney isn't exactly the most famous school abroad so I'm not entirely sure what those demographic statistics are due too. This school is accepting of most white males, so that isn't an issue. The issues tend to be with blacks and gays. There was an instance where a black individual pledged a frat, and a number of fellow pledges dropped out just because the black individual was pledging. Stuff like that is entirely too common here and almost always overlooked.
 I have been part of the group who has simply overlooked these acts and accepted them as just being part of the "Southern tradition." That goes to show how common it is around here, and I won't let that stand anymore. It infuriates me the more I consider it. There is no excuse for it and I should have done or said something about it sooner. No tradition, should it infringe upon the ability of someone to live at ease and in comfort and in freedom, should go unnoticed.
 For these and many other reasons I am asking people to at least write and tell the administration that they think something should be done and give ideas. Voices outside of the school are often more effective than just a few from inside the school.
